==Japanese==

===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|し|にん}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=しにん}} compound {{m|zh|死人|tr=sij<sup>X</sup> nyin|lit=die, death + person}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|しにん|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しにん}}

# a [[dead]] [[person]], the [[dead]]
#: '''(2003)''' {{w|Hellsing}} vol. 6, [[w:en:List_of_Hellsing_chapters|chapter 40]] {{l|ja||最終的な想像 5|Final Fantasy 5}}, page 59:
#:: {{ja-usex|'''死人'''が喋るな！|'''しにん''' が しゃべる な！|The '''dead''' don't speak!}}

=====Synonyms=====
* {{sense|dead person}} {{ja-r|死者|ししゃ}}, {{ja-r|故人|こじん}} {{qualifier|“the departed, the deceased”}}

=====Idioms=====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-r|死人に口無し|しにん に くち なし}}: “the dead have no mouths” → the dead cannot speak: [[dead men tell no tales]] {{qualifier|that is, the dead cannot provide evidence against others}}; alternatively, the dead cannot speak up if the living blame them for things {{qualifier|the more common sense}}
* {{ja-r|死人に妄語|しにん に もうご}}: “telling lies on a dead person” → to [[lie]] and [[pin]] the [[blame]] on a dead person
* {{ja-r|死人に文言|しにん に もんごん}}: “words at a dead person” → to [[lie]] and [[pin]] the [[blame]] on a dead person
* {{ja-r|死人の所には必ず鬼あり|しにん の ところ に は かならず おに あり}}: “there are definitely demons around a dead person” → it is [[bad luck]] to be around a dead person, as the spirits of the deceased become demons and hang around
* {{ja-r|死人を起こして白骨に肉す|しにん を おこして はっこつ に にくす}}: “to raise the dead and put meat on their bleached bones” → a [[metaphor]] for how [[strongly]] one feels [[gratitude]] and [[indebtedness]] to another person, that they would go so far as to bring them back to life
* {{ja-r|死人を証拠にする|しにん を しょうこ に する}}: “to use a dead person as evidence” → to rely on the actions or speech of someone now dead as evidence, even when it is unclear if the dead person actually did or said those things: to [[base]] one's [[case]] on [[shaky]] [[grounds]]
{{der-bottom}}

=====Coordinate terms=====
* {{ja-r|死体|したい}}: a [[corpse]], a [[dead]] [[body]]

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=j|し|ひと|k2=びと|r=y}}
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=しびと|死|tr1=shi|t1=death, dead|人|tr2=hito|t2=person}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> {{rendaku2|sort=しびと|hito|bito}}

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=j|しびと|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しびと}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=しにびと|rare}} a [[dead]] [[person]], the [[dead]]

=====Usage notes=====
The ''shinin'' reading is more common in modern Japanese when this term is used in isolation. The ''shibito'' reading is common in certain derived compounds.

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|死人の枕|しびと の まくら}}: “dead man's pillow”: alternate name for {{m|ja|靫草|tr=utsubogusa}}: {{taxlink|Prunella vulgaris|species|noshow=1}}, {{vern|common self-heal}} or [[heal-all]], an [[edible]] [[herb]]
* {{ja-r|死人花|しびとばな}}: “dead man's flower”: alternate name for {{m|ja|彼岸花|tr=higanbana}}: {{taxlink|Lycoris radiata|species|noshow=1}}, {{vern|red spider lily}} or {{vern|red magic lily}}, a kind of [[flower]]
* {{ja-r|死人色|しびと いろ}}: “dead person's color”: a [[deathly]] [[pallor]], an [[unhealthy]] [[blueish]] [[pale]] color
* {{ja-r|死人草|しびとぐさ}}: “dead man's herb”: alternate name for {{m|ja|彼岸花|tr=higanbana}}: {{taxlink|Lycoris radiata|species|noshow=1}}, {{vern|red spider lily}} or {{vern|red magic lily}}, a kind of [[flower]]
* {{ja-r|死人担|しびと かつぎ}}: “dead person's carrier” → a [[pallbearer]], someone who helps carry the [[coffin]] in a [[funeral]] [[procession]]
* {{ja-r|死人返|しびとがえり}}: “dead person's turn-back” → in [[kabuki]], a [[somersault]] performed from a standing position, done by a [[character]] who has just been killed by a [[sword]]
{{der-bottom}}

===Etymology 3===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|しに|ひと|k2=びと|r=y}}
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=しにびと|死に|tr1=shini|t1=dying, death|人|tr2=hito|t2=person}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> {{rendaku2|sort=しびと|hito|bito}}

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|しにびと|acc=0}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しにびと}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=しにびと|obsolete}} a [[dead]] [[person]], the [[dead]]

=====Usage notes=====
The ''shinin'' reading is more common in modern Japanese.
